About Me
I am a PhD student in the Department of Political Science at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. I work on international relations and political methodology. My main research interests are (i) analyzing the repertoire of violence used by militant actors to understand how group hierarchies and compositions influence their strategic decisions and (ii) how political factors and institutions lead violent groups to commit politically-oriented violent attacks.
I previously received my master’s degree in Political Science from Central European University and I completed my B.A. in International Relations at Bilkent University. Before starting my graduate studies at UNC, I worked as a project assistant at the International Centre for Migration Policy Development for two years.
If you would like to contact me, please feel free to reach out via ozkaraca[at]unc.edu.

Variable Type
For ANOVA tests, it is necessary to have a single continuous quantitative dependent variable (DV) and a qualitative independent variable (IV) with a minimum of two levels.

title: The Basics of Conducting an ANOVA Test in R
text:
Independence
ANOVA tests require that the observations within each group are independent of each other, and this condition can be verified based on the study design. However, a further test, Durbin-Watson test, can be used to assess whether this assumption is satisfied or not in case needed.

title: The Basics of Conducting an ANOVA Test in R
text:
Normality
ANOVA tests require the distribution of the residuals (the differences between the observed values and the predicted values) to be normal. In other words, the residuals should be normally distributed around zero and as a rule of thumb, for large sample sizes, normality is assumed to be satisfied 3. In this regard, there are three ways to check whether this assumption is met.

If normality is not met, the non-parametric test, Kruskal Wallis, should be used instead of ANOVA to see at least one group is statistically different from others.


Via visual depiction -> using Histogram and/or Quantile-Quantile Plot (QQ Plot)
Via statistical testing -> using shapiro.test

the Null Hypothesis (\(H_{0}\)) will be data come from normal distribution, while the alternative hypothesis (\(H_{1}\)) will be data do not come from normal distribution.
In this scenario, having \(p-value>0.05\) will demonstrate that there is not enough evidence to reject the Null Hypothesis (\(H_{0}\)) and therefore this criterion is met.

Both

title: The Basics of Conducting an ANOVA Test in R
text:
Equality of Variances (Homogeneity)
For this premise of the ANOVA test, the variances of the groups should be equal. 3 ways exist to check that assumption;

Via visual depiction -> using Histogram and/or Dot Plot and/or Scale-Location plot from plot() in R.
Via statistical testing -> using Levene’s test and others such as Barlett’s test and etc.

the Null Hypothesis (\(H_{0}\)) is variances within groups are equal, while the alternative hypothesis (\(H_{1}\)) is variances within groups are not equal.
In this scenario, having \(p-value>0.05\) will demonstrate that there is not enough evidence to reject the Null Hypothesis (\(H_{0}\)) and therefore this criterion is met.

Both


If Equality of Variances is not met, Welch ANOVA test should be used

text:
Main Assumptions of ANOVA
ANOVA tests have 4 main assumptions to be inquired on. They are;


Main Assumptions for ANOVA






Assumption
Explanation




Variable Type
For ANOVA tests, it is necessary to have a single continuous quantitative dependent variable (DV) and a qualitative independent variable (IV) with a minimum of two levels.


Independence
ANOVA tests require that the observations within each group are independent of each other, and this condition can be verified based on the study design.


Normality
ANOVA tests require the distribution of the residuals (the differences between the observed values and the predicted values) to be normal. In other words, the residuals should be normally distributed around zero. As a rule of thumb, for large sample sizes, normality is assumed to be satisfied. Note that, if normality is not met, the non-parametric test, Kruskal Wallis test, should be used instead of ANOVA.


Equality of Variances(Homogeneity)
In ANOVA tests, the variances of the groups should be equal. If Equality of Variances is not met, Welch ANOVA test should be used










Two ways to control normality assumption






Via visual depiction -> using Histogram and/or Quantile-Quantile Plot (QQ Plot)
Via statistical testing -> using shapiro.test

In this scenario, having \(p-value>0.05\) will demonstrate that there is not enough evidence to reject the Null Hypothesis (\(H_{0}\)) and therefore this criterion is met.











Two ways to control homogeneity assumption






Via visual depiction -> using Histogram and/or Dot Plot and/or Scale-Location plot from plot() in R.
Via statistical testing -> using Levene’s test and others such as Barlett’s test and etc.

the Null Hypothesis (\(H_{0}\)) is variances within groups are equal, while the alternative hypothesis (\(H_{1}\)) is variances within groups are not equal.

title: Conducting an ANOVA Test in R
text:
Checking assumptions with real-world data
After introducing the dataset and the main premises of ANOVA test, let’s go over whether the ANOVA test we will be conducing satisfies the main assumptions.
Beginning with Variable Type, we have a single continuous quantitative dependent variable (DV), number of terror events for each country annually, and a qualitative independent variable (IV) with a minimum of two levels, the level of economic inequality. So, Variable Type assumption is satisfied.
With regards to the Independence, the events in our dataset are independent from the each other as it is not high likely that number of terror events in one country affects another and etc.
To check Normality assumption, there are two ways, either a visual inspection or a statistical test, to go with. The below panel tab shows both.

HistogramShapiro Test



hist(dataset$count)







shapiro.test(dataset$count)


    Shapiro-Wilk normality test

data:  dataset$count
W = 0.31233, p-value < 0.00000000000000022





With a p-value below 0.05 as a result of the Shapiro test, we can reject the null hypothesis that the data follows a normal distribution, which is not right. However, considering the sample size in our case, we can assume that the normality assumption is met.
As a last assumption, to check Homogeneity, we again have two ways: either a visual inspection or a statistical test. The below panel tab demonstrates the result for both.

HistogramDot PlotLevene’s Test



dataset$economic_inequality <- factor(dataset$economic_inequality, 
                                                  levels = c("High Inequality", "Medium Inequality", "Low Inequality"))

ggplot(dataset, aes(x = count, fill = economic_inequality)) +
  geom_histogram(position = "identity", alpha = 0.6) +
  labs(x = "Value", y = "Frequency") +
  ggtitle("Histograms of Values by Inequality Status") +
  facet_wrap(~ economic_inequality, nrow = 1) +
  theme(legend.position = "none")







ggplot(dataset, aes(x = economic_inequality, y = count)) +
  geom_point()







library(car)

leveneTest(count ~ economic_inequality, data = dataset)

Levene's Test for Homogeneity of Variance (center = median)

Basics of Analysis of Variance Test (ANOVA) and how to conduct it with R
text:
Main Assumptions of ANOVA
ANOVA tests have four main assumptions that need to be examined. These assumptions, listed below along with their explanations, are crucial because if any of them are violated, the result of the ANOVA test cannot be considered statistically significant and therefore reliable.


Main Assumptions for ANOVA






Assumption
Explanation




Variable Type
For ANOVA tests, it is necessary to have a single continuous quantitative dependent variable (DV) and a qualitative independent variable (IV) with a minimum of two levels.


Independence
ANOVA tests require that the observations within each group are independent of each other, and this condition can be verified based on the study design.


Normality
ANOVA tests require the distribution of the residuals (the differences between the observed values and the predicted values) to be normal. In other words, the residuals should be normally distributed around zero. As a rule of thumb, for large sample sizes, normality is assumed to be satisfied. Note that, if normality is not met, the non-parametric test, Kruskal Wallis test, should be used instead of ANOVA.


Equality of Variances(Homogeneity)
In ANOVA tests, the variances of the groups should be equal. If Equality of Variances is not met, Welch ANOVA test should be used










Two ways to control normality assumption for the dependent variable






Via visual depiction -> using Histogram and/or Quantile-Quantile Plot (QQ Plot)
Via statistical testing -> using shapiro.test

the Null Hypothesis (\(H_{0}\)) is the data follows a normal distribution, while the alternative hypothesis (\(H_{1}\)) rejects that.
In this scenario, having \(p-value>0.05\) will demonstrate that there is not enough evidence to reject the Null Hypothesis (\(H_{0}\)) and therefore this criterion is met.











Two ways to control homogeneity assumption for the independent variable






Via visual depiction -> using Histogram and/or Dot Plot and/or Scale-Location plot from plot() in R.
Via statistical testing -> using Levene’s test and others such as Barlett’s test and etc.

the Null Hypothesis (\(H_{0}\)) is variances within groups are equal, while the alternative hypothesis (\(H_{1}\)) is variances within groups are not equal.
In this scenario, having \(p-value>0.05\) will demonstrate that there is not enough evidence to reject the Null Hypothesis (\(H_{0}\)) and therefore this criterion is met.

With regards to the Independence, the events in our dataset are independent from the each other as it is not high likely that number of terror events in one country affects another and etc. So, Independence assumption is satisfied ✅.

title: Basics of Analysis of Variance Test (ANOVA) and how to conduct it with R
text:
Checking ANOVA assumptions
After introducing the main premises of ANOVA test and the dataset, let’s go over whether the ANOVA test we will be pursuing satisfies the main assumptions.
Beginning with Variable Type, we will have a single continuous quantitative dependent variable (DV), which is the number of gold medals received by each category of athletes. In this case, category of athletes will be our qualitative independent variable (IV) with a minimum of two levels, . So, Variable Type assumption is satisfied ✅.
With regards to the Independence, the events in our dataset are independent from the each other as they are the result of each individual competation. So, Independence assumption is also satisfied ✅.
To check Normality assumption, there are two ways, either a visual inspection or a statistical test. Because the sample size for the dependent variable is higher than 5000 and therefore it is above the limit for the shapiro test, I will choose to stick with the visual inspection. The below figure demonstrates the distribution for the dependent variable.






As seen from the figure, the dependent variable follows a slightly normal distribution, in addition to the fact that we have a large sample size in here, we can accept the null hypothesis that he data follows a normal distribution and normality assumption is met ✅.
With a p-value below 0.05 as a result of the Shapiro test, we can reject the null hypothesis that the data follows a normal distribution. However, considering the sample size in our case, we can assume that the normality assumption is met ✅.
As a last step, to check Homogeneity assumption, we again have two options: either a visual inspection or a statistical test. The below panel tab demonstrates the result for both.
Beginning with the histogram, it is evident that the variances within each group are high due to the right-skewed distribution of the number of terror events. Upon examining the dot plot, it becomes apparent that the variances within each group also exhibit a considerable variation. To statistically test this using Levene’s test in the third panel, the resulting p−value is found to be lower than 0.05, indicating sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis that the variances are equal across groups.
